puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message:
There seems to be some misunderstanding here. The admin.conf only contains credentials (CA cert and client cert) for the admin user (ie, the command) to authentication to kube-apiserver. What the "kubeadm upgrade node" retrieves is the k8s cluster configuration, which can be viewed by "kubeadm config view". 

https://v1-19.docs.kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/administer-cluster/kubeadm/kubeadm-upgrade/

If "--kubeconfig" is not specified in the upgrade node command, kubeadm will search in some default locations. (That's why it's still working by removing --kubeconfig).

So it's fine to remove the option, but the comments seem to be incorrect to me.
Any other reason for "NEVER pass the admin.conf"? Otherwise I would say "no need to pass ...".
I will remove the second line of the comment

Since this control plane is only on controllers, we always want admin.conf.
The missing admin.conf only pertains to workers, and therefore only in the kubelet upgrade area.  I am reverting the changes in this section.
The control plane upgrade will never happen on a worker node, so I don't think this change is required.
I will revert this area.
It looks like this will also be a problem on a pure worker node. Runnign this command myself, it seems like it might be ignoring the --kubeconfig parameter.

According to the docs, this command uses different syntax  (--config string)
https://kubernetes.io/docs/reference/setup-tools/kubeadm/kubeadm-config/

When I use that with an invalid path, it fails.

Interesting - the docs indicate that both parameters are valid. The command seems to ignore the kubeconfig parameter. The config parameter is expecting the kubeadm.yaml file - not the admin.conf file. We don't have the kubeadm.yaml file on worker hosts. I think in this case, we probably want to use the kubelet.conf for --kubeconfig and leave off the --config parameter.

However... trying this out myself (with --v=10) shows that without the --config parameter, this command attempts to contact dl.k8s.io to get the list of images. This is bad as it would fail in air gapped environments. I think we need to update this class to generate the config file first, similar to other places in the manifests:
kubeadm --kubeconfig=/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf config view > OUTPUT_FILE

Then OUTPUT_FILE should be passed as the --config parameter.
I will give this a try.
This will be getting the config file from somewhere - we probably should make it explicit.
OK.  So for all 'worker' hosts (even AIO with admin.conf) I will still explicitly point to kubelet.conf
In this case I'd prefer consistency - it should be safe to always use kubelet.conf since this is only running on worker hosts.
I will update the code and comments to always use admin.conf if it exists (ie: controllers), and fallback to kubelet.conf (workers) if it does not.
Looks like this section would also need to be examined.
This is only used by kube-get-paus-image.erb - why not define it there?
I can move it inside.  I was basing the behaviour and syntax on what we were doing at lines 663-666
Change the name.

I will change it to "load k8s pause image" since internally thats the purpose of the template.
I should probably rename the template file also.
I am adding a comment here so reviewers can determine if this pause image code should also be updated.

Yes Bart, I didn't explain well. We also use the same way which is specifying "--kubernetes-version" to get the image list in the playbook.

We can do this to eliminate the "sed".
kubeadm config images list --kubernetes-version v1.18.1 --image-repository registry.local:9001/k8s.gcr.io

But I guess we don't need and we cannot pass --kubeconfig=/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf at this stage as kubelet.conf is generated by the join.

Does that mean this section is fine? 
I think I need to split this review into 2.  One for these pause images, and another to fix the 'upgrade node' being broken for workers.

We need Angie's help here...

The --kubeconfig parameter is definitely incorrect and needs to change to use kubelet.conf. The other problem is that the "kubeadm config images list" is going to attempt to contact the upstream server (k8s.gcr.io), which is either going to give us a potentially incorrect image list (if it is reachable) or fall back to using the local versions (if k8s.gcr.io is not reachable). I don't see a way to tell this command to not contact the upstream server, which is what we really want, so it seems like the solution is to pass the --config parameter which will avoid using the upstream servers (since the config file overrides the registry).

However... the way this manifest is structured, this command is being run before the worker host has joined the cluster. So I expect the solution you created below will not work because the attempt to get the config (with "kubeadm config view") will fail if we haven't joined the cluster yet. Also, the kubelet.conf file probably doesn't exist at this point either for the same reason.

So... one possibility might be to use your solution below, but insert this after the join command (right after 'configure worker node').

Angie - does that sound right?

For the "kubeadm config image list", I think we don't have many choices here. If we consider the image versions gotten from local client is not reliable, then we have to somehow get the config file either copied from controller or generated from template I believe. But we don't like these approach for sure.

Yes, as Bart described, that's how "kubeadm config images list" works. I guess before joining to the cluster, the result of image list and image versions are gotten from local client version.

I suspect we cannot put the image download after the join, as "kubeadm join" tries to pull pause image from local registry then it will end up with the authentication failure.

Angie - I think using the image versions from the local client would be just fine. I assume you mean adding the --kubernetes-version parameter? I tried this and it seems fine to me:
kubeadm config images list --kubernetes-version v1.18.1

This does not attempt to contact the upstream servers and does not rely on having the kubeadm config. So... would an acceptable fix here be to just do:
kubeadm --kubeconfig=/etc/kubernetes/kubelet.conf config images list --kubernetes-version ${version}

Then we would leave the awk/sed as it is. I wonder why we didn't do it this way in the first place? An earlier call to "kubeadm config images list" in this file is already using the --kubernetes-version.

I think we want the same changes here - right? This code also has the same defects:
- admin.conf does not exist on worker hosts
- the "kubeadm config images list" will be attempting to contact k8s.gcr.io, which we want to prevent

In this case we would use $version instead of $upgrade_to_version.
I have made these changes and am trying them out.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/openstack/co.message: is this 300 seconds expirey window optimized value? the actual token expiration is configurable from 0 to infinite, default 1 hour. I am wondering if there is use case to reduce the token experiation to a much small number (to increase security), when the expiration is smaller than this 300 seconds, the token will always be considered expired. I am wondering if it makes sense to set the default to a very small number (e.g 10 or 20), a caller can overwrite it to a longer time when necessary.

The 300 seconds value was added to the code in Jan 2015.  It was not added as part of this bug.
It's use was to prevent a token that was nearing its expiry from being used, especially since some API calls could take up to 5 minutes and could invoke additional API calls passing the same token (nova calling neutron).

I would suggest raising a new launchpad if you think that value needs to be revisited.

validations_common/tests/library/test_ha.message: Is there any way to do this without regex?

Yeah but it's regex.  When we are faced with a problem and we choose regex as a solution, we have two problems. ;-)  Flippant, but the essence of my point is sincere.

I'd like to see a comment clearly expanding the regex to what kind of string is expected please, the line above.  This would be for future developers potentially debugging the regex.

Maybe I didn't express myself correctly. 

I'm not actually using regex at all. These are merely raw strings, that I assert are passed to the `generic_ini_style_conf_parser`. From the pov of the test it is irrelevant what form they have.

It's the `generic_ini_style_conf_parser` function that is supposed to receive these strings as arguments. I haven't written that function, I don't know the rationale behind it. And from the point of the test it doesn't matter. 

I'm merely checking that the code immediately preceding it's call does what it should do. 

This is the code I'm testing:
https://opendev.org/openstack/validations-common/src/branch/master/validations_common/library/haproxy_conf.py#L63-L67

The strings is passed to the `generic_ini_style_conf_parser`, together with path, unchanged. What the `generic_ini_style_conf_parser` does with them doesn't concern the test. 

Now, I can guess as to why they were written that way. Or I can ask strider, since he wrote it. And I can put the explanation, for the use of regex by `generic_ini_style_conf_parser` into the test. But it doesn't fall within the tests scope.
+1 for a proper comment describing the regex.

Hypothetically, we could make an assertion on either a type of the argument (raw string), on the string length, on the presence of specific characters or on the, and this is ironic, regex match. 

With the possible exception of the last option, all of these would somewhat weaken the test. The final option on the other hand is, in my opinion, needlessly opaque and convoluted. 

Simply asserting on the exact string the `generic_ini_style_conf_parser` function receives is both straightforward and strict.

I think I didn't make myself quite clear before.  The point is I still want to know as a future maintainer of this code what exactly line 39 expands to without having to compile it in my brain.  What is being captured with that specific regex?  Can you provide a sample in a comment?

Well, that's kind of a problem. The regex is meant to match line in haproxy configuration file, an option line to be specific. So it is pretty loose, and, as the original author admits, still not matching everything. To elaborate, both of these are valid options:

   option forwardfor
   server 151_256_250_152_35900 151.256.250.152:35900

In short: The regexes are supposed to match all possibilities described here, and some more:
https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/7/html/load_balancer_administration/ch-haproxy-setup-vsa

I can put the link into the comment. Or I can try some examples. But I don't think it's going to help much.

I'm not sure if that is the more profound solution, but it allows at least to override the parameter for testing also in the executor.

If we enable/enforce TLS in the tests before my change above comes in the stack this should be fine and I can simply remove the additional work from that change. If not, it would be great if we could adapt this change here directly, so I don't have to update the _require_tls evaluation again in my change.

It feels like this function is now doing a little too much and it's also hard to see the different ways you can call it. How about adding a `from_config()` class methods to  ZooKeeperConnection that allow creating a connection from a configparser? E.g. something like

class ZooKeeperConnection(object):
    def __init__(
        self,
        hosts: Union[str, List[str]],
        timeout: int = 120,
        tls_key: Optional[str] = None,
        tls_cert: Optional[str] = None,
        tls_ca: Optional[str] = None,
        read_only: bool = False,
        enable_cache: bool = True,
    ):
        self.log = logging.getLogger("zuul.zk.ZooKeeperConnection")
        self.zookeeper: Optional[ZooKeeper] = None
        self.hosts = hosts
        self.timeout = timeout
        self.tls_key = tls_key
        self.tls_cert = tls_cert
        self.tls_ca = tls_ca
        self.read_only = read_only

    def __enter__(self) -> ZooKeeper:
        self.log.debug("Establishing connection...")
        self.zookeeper = self.connect()
        return self.zookeeper

    def __exit__(self, kind: Any, value: Any, traceback: Optional[Any]):
        self.log.debug("Destroying connection...")
        if self.zookeeper:
            self.zookeeper.disconnect()

    def connect(self) -> ZooKeeper:
        zookeeper = zookeeper_class(enable_cache=self.enable_cache)
        zookeeper.client.connect(
            hosts=self.hosts,
            timeout=self.timeout,
            tls_key=self.tls_key,
            tls_cert=self.tls_cert,
            tls_ca=self.tls_ca,
            read_only=self.read_only,
        )
        return zookeeper

    @classmethod
    def from_config(cls, config: configparser.ConfigParser) -> ZooKeeperConnection:
        hosts = get_default(config, "zookeeper", "hosts", None)
        if not hosts:
            raise Exception("The zookeeper hosts config value is required")
        tls_key = get_default(config, "zookeeper", "tls_key")
        tls_cert = get_default(config, "zookeeper", "tls_cert")
        tls_ca = get_default(config, "zookeeper", "tls_ca")
        timeout = float(get_default(config, "zookeeper", "session_timeout", 120))

        return cls(hosts=hosts, tls_key=tls_key, tls_cert=tls_cert, timeout=timeout)

This way you don't need to use a separate `connect_zookeeper()` method and clients can directly use the ZooKeeperConnection wrapper:

    with ZooKeeperConnection.from_config(config) as zk:
        # ...

Or if you want to use the Zookeeper instance directly:

    connection = ZooKeeperConnection.from_config(config)
    self.zk = connection.connect()
Looking at this now, I'm wondering why we need a different ZooKeeperConnection class besides the ZooKeeperClient?
I think we are both wondering if this could be part of the ZooKeeperClient itself.
Same here. I'm a little confused now about ZooKeeperClient vs ZooKeeperConnection.

I think at this point there was no ZooKeeperClient or at least I did not fully see how they interact. Now with a ZooKeeperClient and a ZooKeeperConnection I was just wondering if they could be combined so that we only have one class responsible for working with a Zookeeper connection. Also just making suggestions here to start a discussion :)

ZooKeeperConnection was done to unify/simplify creating a ZooKeeperClient. It provides a way to configure connection using a ConfigParser and using parameters in constructor and can be used with a "with" block. It is a replacement of the previously used "connect_zookeeper" sugar function.

We can do that. The ZooKeeperConnection now deals with parsing configuration while ZooKeeperClient expects already prepared parameters. If there is no benefit of such separation merging those two should not be a problem.
It could of course. I got inspired by your comment at patch 10 ;)

Nothing uses this class, and I'm not sure what the intent is; all of our zk connections are going to be very long lived; essentially, we're never going to close them; why would we do this as a context manager?
Sorry, that should say nothing uses this class as a connection manager.

That's mainly what my cleanup in https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul/+/771442/10 is about. This connection class would be used in the "Connect xyz to ZooKeeper" changes (sometimes as a context manager), but I thought it would be nicer to have only a single class as entry point to ZooKeeper.

As the cleanup mentioned above was previously further up in the stack, I rebased it on top of this change to directly incorporate it as a fixup/squash commit. AFAIK I still have to adapt the "Connect xyz to ZooKeeper" patches to make that fully work as there might be some leftovers from the rebase.
Docstring needs to move to the connect method.  I'll fix this in a new patchset.

this is a bit fragile, as get_by_nodename could raise a ComputeHostNotFound exception in case of a missing compute_nodes record. I'd like if we could be a bit more conservative.

While technically possible it is really unrealistic that ComputeNode record does not exists while the compute RPC was able to send the attach_interface message to this this compute. 

So if this happens then I think we have a big problem we have an instance running on a compute node where the compute node record does not exists. The current interface_attach call will fail with HTTP500 (as no handler is added) which I think is correct as we hit a DB inconsistency at least.

Until this point in the interface_attach process we did not allocated any external resources or modified the DB so nothing to roll back hence there is no except: branch.

I think this is an oversimplification unfortunately. 

Assume we have two network requests req1 is with net_id=1 and req2 is with port_id=2 in the same boot request
Assume that the net_id=1 maps to two segments and therefore two aggregates, agg=1, agg=2
Assume that the port_id=2 maps to a single segment and therefore a single aggregate agg=3

In this case when selecting the compute host for the instance we need to apply the following rule:
* host is in either agg1 or agg2 (to satisfy the req1)
and
* host is in agg3 (to satisfy the req2)

But I think the current code now simply list all the agg1,agg2,agg3 in the required_aggregates which means the host needs to be in agg1 or agg2 or agg3. 

The doc of Destination.require_aggregates() states:

        """Add a set of aggregates to the list of required aggregates.

        This will take a list of aggregates, which are to be logically OR'd
        together and add them to the list of required aggregates that will
        be used to query placement. Aggregate sets provided in sequential calls
        to this method will be AND'd together.

        For example, the following set of calls:
            dest.require_aggregates(['foo', 'bar'])
            dest.require_aggregates(['baz'])
        will generate the following logical query to placement:
            "Candidates should be in 'foo' OR 'bar', but definitely in 'baz'"

So I think you have to make a Destination.require_aggregates() call for each network request to express the AND relationship of the network requests.

This is problematic. In a simple provider net the network will have a segment in neutron. But the subnets on that network might or might not assigned to that segment. If there is no subnet assigned to that segment then the neutron segment plugin did not created placement aggregate configuration so we will end up here. 

Imagine the situation:
1) there is a normal net without any fancy multi-segmentation

  $ openstack network create net3 --share --provider-network-type vlan --provider-physical-network physnet0 --provider-segment 103
  $ openstack subnet create subnet3 --network net3 --subnet-range 10.0.7.0/24 

this is a valid neutron configuration

2) then there is another network with with multiple segments configured accordingly

  $ openstack network create net4 --share --provider-network-type vlan --provider-physical-network physnet0 --provider-segment 104
  $ openstack network segment create --physical-network physnet1 --network-type vlan --segment 3004 --network net4 other-segment
  $ openstack subnet create subnet4 --network net4 --subnet-range 10.0.8.0/24 --network-segment other-segment

this is also a valid neutron configuration

3) now the user boots a VM connected to both network

  $ openstack server create --image cirros-0.5.1-x86_64-disk --flavor c1 --nic net-id=net3 --nic net-id=net4  vm1 --wait

This boot will now fail as nova considers both net3 and net4 having a segment but neutron only created aggregates for net4 but not for net3 and therefore we end up with this exception.

///

I'm not sure if this is bug in the segments plugin in neutron but today the segments plugin only triggered for subnets that has explicit segment_id set. However this prefilter in nova is triggered for any network having a segment even if there is no subnet with that segment.
Re-tested these scenarios with PS22 and now the result looks good to me (except the neutron specific bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1916276)

container-images/tcib/base/os/heat-base/.message: seems like something that makes sense in os-base since it's likely needed across the board for all openstack services
Right thats my point in that this will likely be a more global requirement than only for these services in the future. If the two packages can co-exist, I would just move it to os-base.

To give context, Only these 4 services support oslo.cache -> dogpile.cache -> pymemcache combo. The other services connect to memcached via the authtoken middleware (which doesn't use oslo.cache), have their own memcache client (swift), or don't support pymemcache yet (horizon's version of django). Authtoken middleware may likely use pymemcache in the future but this is undecided yet. Currently it has the option of encrypting the session information it stores in memcache, but doesn't support TLS.

So I'm not sure, with the above context, are you of the opinion we could add it in os-base, or change it in the future, once we implement memcached TLS in horizon and authtoken middleware?

Also, probably all projects will stop using python-memcached, since it was abandoned 4 years ago https://github.com/linsomniac/python-memcached/issues/95

This is not specific for this change and should be discussed in the follow up, but I feel it is not very useful but just confusing to have backup driver options overridable.

We don't really expect our users to override driver path, thus it makes sense to deprecate the driver parameters and make them hard-coded.

I agree we "don't expect" users to override the driver path, but the pattern of providing that ability has been present in the code for a long time, and I don't see a lot of value in removing flexibility.

In fact, I know of one situation where the capability was useful for a Red Hat customer. The situation was unusual, but my point is simply that the feature has proven useful in addressing unexpected corner cases.

Well, bear in mind there's a larger issue at stack. There have been occasional requests for cinder to support multiple backup backends (similar to the volume service). # DEPRECATED
# "baremetal:node:list":"rule:baremetal:node:get" has been deprecated
# since W in favor of "baremetal:node:list":"role:reader and
# system_scope:all".
# The baremetal node API is now aware of system scope and default

# configuration will be removed in the Xena release of Ironic.

The convert_mapping_to_xml handles optionals too. I'd create a separate mapping variable for optional parameters like:

 optional_mapping = [("pending-build-name", "pendingBuildName", None)]
